ML_Engine.visualization package¶

Visualization Sub-package¶

A comprehensive toolkit for creating data science and model evaluation plots.

This package provides modules for different plot types: - distribution: For visualizing single variables. - relationship: For visualizing relationships between two or more variables. - categorical: For visualizing categorical data. - matrix: For matrix-style plots like heatmaps. - evaluation: For model performance plots. - style: For managing plot aesthetics.

Submodules¶

ML_Engine.visualization.categorical module¶

Categorical Plots¶

Functions for visualizing categorical data.

ML_Engine.visualization.categorical.plot_barplot(data: DataFrame, x: str, y: str, hue: str | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a bar plot.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • y (str) – Column name for the y-axis.

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.barplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.categorical.plot_countplot(data: DataFrame, x: str, hue: str | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a count plot showing the counts of observations in each categorical bin.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.countplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.distribution module¶

Distribution Plots¶

Functions for visualizing the distribution of single variables.

ML_Engine.visualization.distribution.plot_boxplot(data: DataFrame, x: str, y: str | None = None, hue: str | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a box plot to show distribution quartiles and outliers.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis (can be categorical or numeric).

  • y (str, optional) – Column name for the y-axis (usually numeric if x is categorical).

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object to draw the plot onto.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.boxplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.distribution.plot_distribution_summary(data: DataFrame, x: str, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), title: str | None = None) → Figure[source]¶

Create a summary figure with Histogram, Box Plot, and Q-Q Plot for a variable.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name to analyze.

  • figsize (tuple, default=(12, 8)) – Size of the figure.

  • title (str, optional) – Main title for the figure.

Returns:

The created figure object.

Return type:

plt.Figure

ML_Engine.visualization.distribution.plot_histogram(data: DataFrame, x: str, hue: str | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, kde: bool = True, bins: str | int = 'auto', **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a histogram with optional KDE.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object to draw the plot onto.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • kde (bool, default=True) – Whether to plot a gaussian kernel density estimate.

  • bins (str or int, default='auto') – Specification of hist bins.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.histplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.distribution.plot_kde(data: DataFrame, x: str, hue: str | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, fill: bool = True, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a Kernel Density Estimate (KDE).

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object to draw the plot onto.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • fill (bool, default=True) – Whether to fill the area under the curve.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.kdeplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.distribution.plot_qq(data: DataFrame, x: str, dist: str = 'norm', ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a Q-Q plot to compare data distribution against a theoretical distribution.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name containing the data to check.

  • dist (str, default="norm") – Theoretical distribution to compare against (e.g., ‘norm’, ‘expon’).

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object to draw the plot onto.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to stats.probplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.eda module¶

ML_Engine.visualization.eda.plot_correlations(df: DataFrame)[source]¶

Computes the correlation matrix for the numeric columns of a DataFrame and renders it as a heatmap.

Parameters:

df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame.

Returns:

The figure object containing the heatmap.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

ML_Engine.visualization.eda.plot_dataset_overview(df: DataFrame, target: str = None)[source]¶

Automatically generates a grid of histograms for numeric columns and countplots for categorical columns to provide a visual overview of the dataset.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame.

  • target (str, optional) – The name of the target variable. If provided, it will be excluded from the overview plots.

Returns:

The figure object containing the plots.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

ML_Engine.visualization.eda.plot_pairplot(df: DataFrame, hue: str = None, max_cols: int = 5)[source]¶

Generates a pairplot for a subset of numeric columns in the DataFrame. Uses seaborn directly for this high-level plot.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame.

  • hue (str, optional) – Variable in df to map plot aspects to different colors.

  • max_cols (int, optional) – The maximum number of numeric columns to include in the pairplot to avoid performance issues. Defaults to 5.

Returns:

The PairGrid object.

Return type:

seaborn.axisgrid.PairGrid

ML_Engine.visualization.eda.plot_target_analysis(df: DataFrame, target: str)[source]¶

Provides a visual summary of the target variable, including its distribution, class balance (for classification), or outliers (for regression).

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame.

  • target (str) – The name of the target variable column.

Returns:

The figure object containing the plot(s).

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

ML_Engine.visualization.evaluation module¶

Model Evaluation Plots¶

Functions for visualizing model performance.

ML_Engine.visualization.evaluation.plot_confusion_matrix(y_true: ndarray | Series, y_pred: ndarray | Series, labels: List[str] | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str = 'Confusion Matrix', cmap: str = 'Blues', **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a confusion matrix.

Parameters:

  • y_true (array-like) – True labels.

  • y_pred (array-like) – Predicted labels.

  • labels (list of str, optional) – List of label names to use on the x and y axes.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, default='Confusion Matrix') – Plot title.

  • cmap (str, default='Blues') – Colormap for the heatmap.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.heatmap.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.evaluation.plot_precision_recall_curve(y_true: ndarray | Series, y_prob: ndarray | Series, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str = 'Precision-Recall Curve', **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot the Precision-Recall curve.

Parameters:

  • y_true (array-like) – True binary labels.

  • y_prob (array-like) – Target scores.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, default='Precision-Recall Curve') – Plot title.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to plt.plot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.evaluation.plot_roc_curve(y_true: ndarray | Series, y_prob: ndarray | Series, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str = 'ROC Curve', **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve.

Parameters:

  • y_true (array-like) – True binary labels.

  • y_prob (array-like) – Target scores, can either be probability estimates of the positive class or confidence values.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, default='ROC Curve') – Plot title.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to plt.plot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.features module¶

Feature-related Plots¶

Functions for visualizing feature characteristics.

ML_Engine.visualization.features.plot_variance(data: DataFrame, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str = 'Feature Variances', xlabel: str = 'Features', ylabel: str = 'Variance', show_values: bool = True, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot feature variances as a bar chart.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data containing the features.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, default='Feature Variances') – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, default='Features') – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, default='Variance') – Label for the y-axis.

  • show_values (bool, default=True) – Whether to show variance values on bars.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.barplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.matrix module¶

Matrix Plots¶

Functions for visualizing matrix-like data, such as correlation matrices.

ML_Engine.visualization.matrix.plot_heatmap(data: DataFrame, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, annot: bool = True, cmap: str = 'coolwarm', **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a heatmap.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data, typically a correlation matrix.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • annot (bool, default=True) – If True, write the data value in each cell.

  • cmap (str, default='coolwarm') – The mapping from data values to color space.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.heatmap.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.relationship module¶

Relationship Plots¶

Functions for visualizing relationships between variables.

Plot a line plot.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • y (str) – Column name for the y-axis.

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • style (str, optional) – Column name for line style encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.lineplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

Parameters:

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • y (str) – Column name for the y-axis.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.regplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.relationship.plot_scatter(data: DataFrame, x: str, y: str, hue: str | None = None, style: str | None = None, size: str | None = None, ax: Axes | None = None, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Axes[source]¶

Plot a scatter plot.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Input data.

  • x (str) – Column name for the x-axis.

  • y (str) – Column name for the y-axis.

  • hue (str, optional) – Column name for color encoding.

  • style (str, optional) – Column name for marker style encoding.

  • size (str, optional) – Column name for marker size encoding.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Matplotlib axes object.

  • title (str, optional) – Plot title.

  • xlabel (str, optional) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str, optional) – Label for the y-axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.scatterplot.

Returns:

The axes object containing the plot.

Return type:

plt.Axes

ML_Engine.visualization.style module¶

Visualization Style Management¶

Functions for managing plot aesthetics, themes, and configurations.

ML_Engine.visualization.style.get_current_style() → Dict[str, Any][source]¶

Get the current matplotlib rcParams.

Returns:

Current configuration dictionary.

Return type:

dict

ML_Engine.visualization.style.reset_style()[source]¶

Reset matplotlib parameters to defaults.

ML_Engine.visualization.style.set_style(style: str = 'whitegrid', context: str = 'notebook', palette: str = 'deep', font_scale: float = 1.0, rc: Dict[str, Any] | None = None)[source]¶

Set the global plotting style and aesthetics.

Parameters:

  • style (str, default='whitegrid') – Seaborn style (‘darkgrid’, ‘whitegrid’, ‘dark’, ‘white’, ‘ticks’).

  • context (str, default='notebook') – Seaborn context (‘paper’, ‘notebook’, ‘talk’, ‘poster’).

  • palette (str, default='deep') – Color palette name.

  • font_scale (float, default=1.0) – Scaling factor for font sizes.

  • rc (dict, optional) – Dictionary of rc parameters to override defaults.

ML_Engine.visualization.timeseries module¶

ML_Engine.visualization.timeseries.plot_acf_pacf(series: Series, lags: int = 40)[source]¶

Plots the AutoCorrelation Function (ACF) and Partial AutoCorrelation Function (PACF) for a time series.

Parameters:

  • series (pd.Series) – The time series data.

  • lags (int, optional) – The number of lags to plot. Defaults to 40.

Returns:

The figure object containing the ACF and PACF plots.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

Raises:

ImportError – If statsmodels is not installed.

ML_Engine.visualization.timeseries.plot_rolling_statistics(df: DataFrame, col: str, window: int)[source]¶

Plots the original time series along with its rolling mean and standard deviation.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame.

  • col (str) – The name of the column to analyze.

  • window (int) – The size of the rolling window.

Returns:

The figure object containing the plot.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

ML_Engine.visualization.timeseries.plot_seasonality_decomposition(series: Series, period: int)[source]¶

Performs seasonal decomposition and plots the trend, seasonal, and residual components.

Parameters:

  • series (pd.Series) – The time series data.

  • period (int) – The period of the seasonality (e.g., 12 for monthly data with yearly seasonality).

Returns:

The figure object containing the decomposition plots.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

Raises:

ImportError – If statsmodels is not installed.

ML_Engine.visualization.timeseries.plot_timeseries(df: DataFrame, date_col: str, value_col: str)[source]¶

Plots a time series with the date on the x-axis and a specified value on the y-axis.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame.

  • date_col (str) – The name of the date column.

  • value_col (str) – The name of the column with values to plot.

Returns:

The figure object containing the plot.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure
